segment.source: 4673(S, F) A privileged service was called.
segment.target: 4673(S, F) A privileged service was called.

segment.source: (Windows 10)
segment.target: (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes security event 4673(S, F) A privileged service was called.
segment.target: Describes security event 4673(S, F) A privileged service was called.

segment.source: 4673(S, F): A privileged service was called.
segment.target: 4673(S, F): A privileged service was called.

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016
segment.target: Windows Server 2016

segment.source:
Subcategories:
Audit Sensitive Privilege Use and Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target:
Subcategories:
Audit Sensitive Privilege Use and Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: Event Description:
segment.target: Event Description:

segment.source: This event generates when an attempt was made to perform privileged system service operations.
segment.target: This event generates when an attempt was made to perform privileged system service operations.

segment.source: This event generates, for example, when SeSystemtimePrivilege, SeCreateGlobalPrivilege, or SeTcbPrivilege privilege was used.
segment.target: This event generates, for example, when SeSystemtimePrivilege, SeCreateGlobalPrivilege, or SeTcbPrivilege privilege was used.

segment.source: Failure event generates when service call attempt fails.
segment.target: Failure event generates when service call attempt fails.

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Event XML:
segment.target: Event XML:

segment.source: Required Server Roles: None.
segment.target: Required Server Roles: None.

segment.source: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.
segment.target: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.

segment.source: Event Versions: 0.
segment.target: Event Versions: 0.

segment.source: Field Descriptions:
segment.target: Field Descriptions:

segment.source: Subject:
segment.target: Subject:

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested privileged operation.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested privileged operation.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).
segment.target: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).

segment.source: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.
segment.target: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.

segment.source: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.

segment.source: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.
segment.target: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.
segment.target: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested privileged operation.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested privileged operation.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO

segment.source: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local
segment.target: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local

segment.source: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.
segment.target: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.

segment.source: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.
segment.target: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.

segment.source: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”
segment.target: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”

segment.source: Service:
segment.target: Service:

segment.source: Server Type = UnicodeString: contains the name of the Windows subsystem calling the routine.
segment.target: Server Type = UnicodeString: contains the name of the Windows subsystem calling the routine.

segment.source: Subsystems examples are:
segment.target: Subsystems examples are:

segment.source: Security
segment.target: Security

segment.source: Security Account Manager
segment.target: Security Account Manager

segment.source: NT Local Security Authority / Authentication Service
segment.target: NT Local Security Authority / Authentication Service

segment.source: SC Manager
segment.target: SC Manager

segment.source: Win32 SystemShutdown module
segment.target: Win32 SystemShutdown module

segment.source: LSA
segment.target: LSA

segment.source: Service Name Type = UnicodeStringOptional: supplies a name of the privileged subsystem service or function.
segment.target: Service Name Type = UnicodeStringOptional: supplies a name of the privileged subsystem service or function.

segment.source: For example, "RESET RUNTIME LOCAL SECURITY" might be specified by a Local Security Authority service used to update the local security policy database or LsaRegisterLogonProcess() might be specified by a NT Local Security Authority / Authentication Service used to register new logon process.
segment.target: For example, "RESET RUNTIME LOCAL SECURITY" might be specified by a Local Security Authority service used to update the local security policy database or LsaRegisterLogonProcess() might be specified by a NT Local Security Authority / Authentication Service used to register new logon process.

segment.source: Process:
segment.target: Process:

segment.source: Process ID Type = Pointer: hexadecimal Process ID of the process that attempted to call the privileged service.
segment.target: Process ID Type = Pointer: hexadecimal Process ID of the process that attempted to call the privileged service.

segment.source: Process ID (PID) is a number used by the operating system to uniquely identify an active process.
segment.target: Process ID (PID) is a number used by the operating system to uniquely identify an active process.

segment.source: To see the PID for a specific process you can, for example, use Task Manager (Details tab, PID column):
segment.target: To see the PID for a specific process you can, for example, use Task Manager (Details tab, PID column):

segment.source: If you convert the hexadecimal value to decimal, you can compare it to the values in Task Manager.
segment.target: If you convert the hexadecimal value to decimal, you can compare it to the values in Task Manager.

segment.source: You can also correlate this process ID with a process ID in other events, for example, “4688: A new process has been created” Process InformationNew Process ID.
segment.target: You can also correlate this process ID with a process ID in other events, for example, “4688: A new process has been created” Process InformationNew Process ID.

segment.source: Process Name Type = UnicodeString: full path and the name of the executable for the process.
segment.target: Process Name Type = UnicodeString: full path and the name of the executable for the process.

segment.source: Service Request Information:
segment.target: Service Request Information:

segment.source: Privileges Type = UnicodeString: the list of user privileges which were requested.
segment.target: Privileges Type = UnicodeString: the list of user privileges which were requested.

segment.source: The possible privileges depend on the subcategory, either Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use or Audit Sensitive Privilege Use, as shown in the following two tables:
segment.target: The possible privileges depend on the subcategory, either Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use or Audit Sensitive Privilege Use, as shown in the following two tables:

segment.source: Subcategory of event
segment.target: Subcategory of event

segment.source: Privilege Name:
segment.target: Privilege Name:

segment.target: User Right Group Policy Name

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeChangeNotifyPrivilege: Bypass traverse checking
segment.target: SeChangeNotifyPrivilege: Bypass traverse checking

segment.source: Required to receive notifications of changes to files or directories.
segment.target: Required to receive notifications of changes to files or directories.

segment.source: This privilege also causes the system to skip all traversal access checks.
segment.target: This privilege also causes the system to skip all traversal access checks.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can traverse directory trees even though the user may not have permissions on the traversed directory.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can traverse directory trees even though the user may not have permissions on the traversed directory.

segment.source: This privilege does not allow the user to list the contents of a directory, only to traverse directories.
segment.target: This privilege does not allow the user to list the contents of a directory, only to traverse directories.

segment.source: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeCreateGlobalPrivilege: Create global objects
segment.target: SeCreateGlobalPrivilege: Create global objects

segment.source: Required to create named file mapping objects in the global namespace during Terminal Services sessions.
segment.target: Required to create named file mapping objects in the global namespace during Terminal Services sessions.

segment.source: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeCreatePagefilePrivilege: Create a pagefile
segment.target: SeCreatePagefilePrivilege: Create a pagefile

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can create and change the size of a pagefile.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can create and change the size of a pagefile.

segment.source: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeCreatePermanentPrivilege: Create permanent shared objects
segment.target: SeCreatePermanentPrivilege: Create permanent shared objects

segment.source: Required to create a permanent object.
segment.target: Required to create a permanent object.

segment.source: This privilege is useful to kernel-mode components that extend the object namespace.
segment.target: This privilege is useful to kernel-mode components that extend the object namespace.

segment.source: Components that are running in kernel mode already have this privilege inherently; it is not necessary to assign them the privilege.
segment.target: Components that are running in kernel mode already have this privilege inherently; it is not necessary to assign them the privilege.

segment.source: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeCreateSymbolicLinkPrivilege: Create symbolic links
segment.target: SeCreateSymbolicLinkPrivilege: Create symbolic links

segment.source: Required to create a symbolic link.
segment.target: Required to create a symbolic link.

segment.source: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeIncreaseBasePriorityPrivilege: Increase scheduling priority
segment.target: SeIncreaseBasePriorityPrivilege: Increase scheduling priority

segment.source: Required to increase the base priority of a process.
segment.target: Required to increase the base priority of a process.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can use a process with Write property access to another process to increase the execution priority assigned to the other process.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can use a process with Write property access to another process to increase the execution priority assigned to the other process.

segment.source: A user with this privilege can change the scheduling priority of a process through the Task Manager user interface.
segment.target: A user with this privilege can change the scheduling priority of a process through the Task Manager user interface.

segment.source: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeIncreaseQuotaPrivilege: Adjust memory quotas for a process
segment.target: SeIncreaseQuotaPrivilege: Adjust memory quotas for a process

segment.source: Required to increase the quota assigned to a process.
segment.target: Required to increase the quota assigned to a process.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can change the maximum memory that can be consumed by a process.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can change the maximum memory that can be consumed by a process.

segment.source: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeIncreaseWorkingSetPrivilege: Increase a process working set
segment.target: SeIncreaseWorkingSetPrivilege: Increase a process working set

segment.source: Required to allocate more memory for applications that run in the context of users.
segment.target: Required to allocate more memory for applications that run in the context of users.

segment.source: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeLockMemoryPrivilege: Lock pages in memory
segment.target: SeLockMemoryPrivilege: Lock pages in memory

segment.source: Required to lock physical pages in memory.
segment.target: Required to lock physical pages in memory.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can use a process to keep data in physical memory, which prevents the system from paging the data to virtual memory on disk.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can use a process to keep data in physical memory, which prevents the system from paging the data to virtual memory on disk.

segment.source: Exercising this privilege could significantly affect system performance by decreasing the amount of available random access memory (RAM).
segment.target: Exercising this privilege could significantly affect system performance by decreasing the amount of available random access memory (RAM).

segment.source: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeMachineAccountPrivilege: Add workstations to domain
segment.target: SeMachineAccountPrivilege: Add workstations to domain

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can create a computer account.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can create a computer account.

segment.source: This privilege is valid only on domain controllers.
segment.target: This privilege is valid only on domain controllers.

segment.source: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeManageVolumePrivilege: Perform volume maintenance tasks
segment.target: SeManageVolumePrivilege: Perform volume maintenance tasks

segment.source: Required to run maintenance tasks on a volume, such as remote defragmentation.
segment.target: Required to run maintenance tasks on a volume, such as remote defragmentation.

segment.source: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeProfileSingleProcessPrivilege: Profile single process
segment.target: SeProfileSingleProcessPrivilege: Profile single process

segment.source: Required to gather profiling information for a single process.
segment.target: Required to gather profiling information for a single process.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can use performance monitoring tools to monitor the performance of non-system processes.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can use performance monitoring tools to monitor the performance of non-system processes.

segment.source: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeRelabelPrivilege: Modify an object label
segment.target: SeRelabelPrivilege: Modify an object label

segment.source: Required to modify the mandatory integrity level of an object.
segment.target: Required to modify the mandatory integrity level of an object.

segment.source: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeRemoteShutdownPrivilege: Force shutdown from a remote system
segment.target: SeRemoteShutdownPrivilege: Force shutdown from a remote system

segment.source: Required to shut down a system using a network request.
segment.target: Required to shut down a system using a network request.

segment.source: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeShutdownPrivilege: Shut down the system
segment.target: SeShutdownPrivilege: Shut down the system

segment.source: Required to shut down a local system.
segment.target: Required to shut down a local system.

segment.source: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeSyncAgentPrivilege: Synchronize directory service data
segment.target: SeSyncAgentPrivilege: Synchronize directory service data

segment.source: This privilege enables the holder to read all objects and properties in the directory, regardless of the protection on the objects and properties.
segment.target: This privilege enables the holder to read all objects and properties in the directory, regardless of the protection on the objects and properties.

segment.source: By default, it is assigned to the Administrator and LocalSystem accounts on domain controllers.
segment.target: By default, it is assigned to the Administrator and LocalSystem accounts on domain controllers.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can synchronize all directory service data.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can synchronize all directory service data.

segment.source: This is also known as Active Directory synchronization.
segment.target: This is also known as Active Directory synchronization.

segment.source: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeSystemProfilePrivilege: Profile system performance
segment.target: SeSystemProfilePrivilege: Profile system performance

segment.source: Required to gather profiling information for the entire system.
segment.target: Required to gather profiling information for the entire system.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can use performance monitoring tools to monitor the performance of system processes.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can use performance monitoring tools to monitor the performance of system processes.

segment.source: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeSystemtimePrivilege: Change the system time
segment.target: SeSystemtimePrivilege: Change the system time

segment.source: Required to modify the system time.
segment.target: Required to modify the system time.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can change the time and date on the internal clock of the computer.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can change the time and date on the internal clock of the computer.

segment.source: Users that are assigned this user right can affect the appearance of event logs.
segment.target: Users that are assigned this user right can affect the appearance of event logs.

segment.source: If the system time is changed, events that are logged will reflect this new time, not the actual time that the events occurred.
segment.target: If the system time is changed, events that are logged will reflect this new time, not the actual time that the events occurred.

segment.source: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeTimeZonePrivilege: Change the time zone
segment.target: SeTimeZonePrivilege: Change the time zone

segment.source: Required to adjust the time zone associated with the computer's internal clock.
segment.target: Required to adjust the time zone associated with the computer's internal clock.

segment.source: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeTrustedCredManAccessPrivilege: Access Credential Manager as a trusted caller
segment.target: SeTrustedCredManAccessPrivilege: Access Credential Manager as a trusted caller

segment.source: Required to access Credential Manager as a trusted caller.
segment.target: Required to access Credential Manager as a trusted caller.

segment.source: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeUndockPrivilege: Remove computer from docking station
segment.target: SeUndockPrivilege: Remove computer from docking station

segment.source: Required to undock a laptop.
segment.target: Required to undock a laptop.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can undock a portable computer from its docking station without logging on.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can undock a portable computer from its docking station without logging on.

segment.source: Subcategory of event
segment.target: Subcategory of event

segment.source: Privilege Name:
segment.target: Privilege Name:

segment.source: User Right Group Policy Name
segment.target: User Right Group Policy Name

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Audit Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeAssignPrimaryTokenPrivilege: Replace a process-level token
segment.target: SeAssignPrimaryTokenPrivilege: Replace a process-level token

segment.source: Required to assign the primary token of a process.
segment.target: Required to assign the primary token of a process.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can initiate a process to replace the default token associated with a started subprocess.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can initiate a process to replace the default token associated with a started subprocess.

segment.source: Audit Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeAuditPrivilege: Generate security audits
segment.target: SeAuditPrivilege: Generate security audits

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can add entries to the security log.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can add entries to the security log.

segment.source: Audit Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeCreateTokenPrivilege: Create a token object
segment.target: SeCreateTokenPrivilege: Create a token object

segment.source: Allows a process to create a token which it can then use to get access to any local resources when the process uses NtCreateToken() or other token-creation APIs.
segment.target: Allows a process to create a token which it can then use to get access to any local resources when the process uses NtCreateToken() or other token-creation APIs.

segment.source: When a process requires this privilege, we recommend using the LocalSystem account (which already includes the privilege), rather than creating a separate user account and assigning this privilege to it.
segment.target: When a process requires this privilege, we recommend using the LocalSystem account (which already includes the privilege), rather than creating a separate user account and assigning this privilege to it.

segment.source: Audit Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeDebugPrivilege: Debug programs
segment.target: SeDebugPrivilege: Debug programs

segment.source: Required to debug and adjust the memory of a process owned by another account.
segment.target: Required to debug and adjust the memory of a process owned by another account.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can attach a debugger to any process or to the kernel.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can attach a debugger to any process or to the kernel.

segment.source: Developers who are debugging their own applications do not need this user right.
segment.target: Developers who are debugging their own applications do not need this user right.

segment.source: Developers who are debugging new system components need this user right.
segment.target: Developers who are debugging new system components need this user right.

segment.source: This user right provides complete access to sensitive and critical operating system components.
segment.target: This user right provides complete access to sensitive and critical operating system components.

segment.source: Audit Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeImpersonatePrivilege: Impersonate a client after authentication
segment.target: SeImpersonatePrivilege: Impersonate a client after authentication

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can impersonate other accounts.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can impersonate other accounts.

segment.source: Audit Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeLoadDriverPrivilege: Load and unload device drivers
segment.target: SeLoadDriverPrivilege: Load and unload device drivers

segment.source: Required to load or unload a device driver.
segment.target: Required to load or unload a device driver.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can dynamically load and unload device drivers or other code in to kernel mode.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can dynamically load and unload device drivers or other code in to kernel mode.

segment.source: This user right does not apply to Plug and Play device drivers.
segment.target: This user right does not apply to Plug and Play device drivers.

segment.source: Audit Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeLockMemoryPrivilege: Lock pages in memory
segment.target: SeLockMemoryPrivilege: Lock pages in memory

segment.source: Required to lock physical pages in memory.
segment.target: Required to lock physical pages in memory.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can use a process to keep data in physical memory, which prevents the system from paging the data to virtual memory on disk.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can use a process to keep data in physical memory, which prevents the system from paging the data to virtual memory on disk.

segment.source: Exercising this privilege could significantly affect system performance by decreasing the amount of available random access memory (RAM).
segment.target: Exercising this privilege could significantly affect system performance by decreasing the amount of available random access memory (RAM).

segment.source: Audit Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeSystemEnvironmentPrivilege: Modify firmware environment values
segment.target: SeSystemEnvironmentPrivilege: Modify firmware environment values

segment.source: Required to modify the nonvolatile RAM of systems that use this type of memory to store configuration information.
segment.target: Required to modify the nonvolatile RAM of systems that use this type of memory to store configuration information.

segment.source: Audit Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeTcbPrivilege: Act as part of the operating system
segment.target: SeTcbPrivilege: Act as part of the operating system

segment.source: This privilege identifies its holder as part of the trusted computer base.
segment.target: This privilege identifies its holder as part of the trusted computer base.

segment.source: This user right allows a process to impersonate any user without authentication.
segment.target: This user right allows a process to impersonate any user without authentication.

segment.source: The process can therefore gain access to the same local resources as that user.
segment.target: The process can therefore gain access to the same local resources as that user.

segment.source: Audit Sensitive Privilege Use
segment.target: Audit Sensitive Privilege Use

segment.source: SeEnableDelegationPrivilege: Enable computer and user accounts to be trusted for delegation
segment.target: SeEnableDelegationPrivilege: Enable computer and user accounts to be trusted for delegation

segment.source: Required to mark user and computer accounts as trusted for delegation.
segment.target: Required to mark user and computer accounts as trusted for delegation.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can set the Trusted for Delegation setting on a user or computer object.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can set the Trusted for Delegation setting on a user or computer object.

segment.source: The user or object that is granted this privilege must have write access to the account control flags on the user or computer object.
segment.target: The user or object that is granted this privilege must have write access to the account control flags on the user or computer object.

segment.source: A server process running on a computer (or under a user context) that is trusted for delegation can access resources on another computer using the delegated credentials of a client, as long as the account of the client does not have the Account cannot be delegated account control flag set.
segment.target: A server process running on a computer (or under a user context) that is trusted for delegation can access resources on another computer using the delegated credentials of a client, as long as the account of the client does not have the Account cannot be delegated account control flag set.

segment.source: Security Monitoring Recommendations
segment.target: Security Monitoring Recommendations

segment.source: For 4673(S, F): A privileged service was called.
segment.target: For 4673(S, F): A privileged service was called.

segment.source: Important For this event, also see Appendix A: Security monitoring recommendations for many audit events.
segment.target: Important For this event, also see Appendix A: Security monitoring recommendations for many audit events.

segment.source: Monitor for this event where “SubjectSecurity ID” is not one of these well-known security principals: LOCAL SYSTEM, NETWORK SERVICE, LOCAL SERVICE, and where “SubjectSecurity ID” is not an administrative account that is expected to have the listed Privileges.
segment.target: Monitor for this event where “SubjectSecurity ID” is not one of these well-known security principals: LOCAL SYSTEM, NETWORK SERVICE, LOCAL SERVICE, and where “SubjectSecurity ID” is not an administrative account that is expected to have the listed Privileges.

segment.source: Especially monitor Failure events.
segment.target: Especially monitor Failure events.

segment.source: If you need to monitor events related to specific Windows subsystems (“ServiceServer”), for example NT Local Security Authority / Authentication Service or Security Account Manager, monitor this event for the corresponding “ServiceServer.”
segment.target: If you need to monitor events related to specific Windows subsystems (“ServiceServer”), for example NT Local Security Authority / Authentication Service or Security Account Manager, monitor this event for the corresponding “ServiceServer.”

segment.source: If you need to monitor events related to specific Windows security services or functions (“ServiceService Name”), for example LsaRegisterLogonProcess(), monitor this event for the corresponding “ServiceService Name.”
segment.target: If you need to monitor events related to specific Windows security services or functions (“ServiceService Name”), for example LsaRegisterLogonProcess(), monitor this event for the corresponding “ServiceService Name.”

segment.source: If you have a pre-defined “Process Name” for the process reported in this event, monitor all events with “Process Name” not equal to your defined value.
segment.target: If you have a pre-defined “Process Name” for the process reported in this event, monitor all events with “Process Name” not equal to your defined value.

segment.source: You can monitor to see if “Process Name” is not in a standard folder (for example, not in System32 or Program Files) or is in a restricted folder (for example, Temporary Internet Files).
segment.target: You can monitor to see if “Process Name” is not in a standard folder (for example, not in System32 or Program Files) or is in a restricted folder (for example, Temporary Internet Files).

segment.source: If you have a pre-defined list of restricted substrings or words in process names (for example, “mimikatz” or “cain.exe”), check for these substrings in “Process Name.”
segment.target: If you have a pre-defined list of restricted substrings or words in process names (for example, “mimikatz” or “cain.exe”), check for these substrings in “Process Name.”

segment.source: For a specific “SubjectSecurity ID,” if there is a defined list of allowed privileges, monitor for “Privileges” that it should not be able to use.
segment.target: For a specific “SubjectSecurity ID,” if there is a defined list of allowed privileges, monitor for “Privileges” that it should not be able to use.

segment.source: If you have a list of specific user rights which should never be used, or used only by a few accounts (for example, SeDebugPrivilege), trigger an alert for those “Privileges.”
segment.target: If you have a list of specific user rights which should never be used, or used only by a few accounts (for example, SeDebugPrivilege), trigger an alert for those “Privileges.”

segment.source: If you have a list of specific user rights for which every use must be reported or monitored (for example, SeRemoteShutdownPrivilege), trigger an alert for those “Privileges.”
segment.target: If you have a list of specific user rights for which every use must be reported or monitored (for example, SeRemoteShutdownPrivilege), trigger an alert for those “Privileges.”
